reporting_cycle: The Panel of Experts shall provide to the Council an interim report on its work no later than 15 September 2020, and a final report to the Council, after discussion with the Committee, no later than 15 March 2021
summary:
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Recalling previous resolutions on Libya, reaffirms its commitment to Libya's sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity.

Condemns attempts to illicitly export petroleum from Libya, including by parallel institutions not under the Government of National Accord (GNA).

Decides to extend until 30 April 2021 the authorisations and measures imposed by resolution 2146 (2014) to prevent illicit exports of petroleum.

Requests the GNA to work closely with the National Oil Company to provide regular updates to the Committee on ports, oil fields, and installations under its control.

Calls on the GNA to expeditiously contact the concerned vessel's flag State to resolve issues related to illicit exports or attempted exports.

Welcomes the appointment of a focal point by the GNA to communicate with the Committee on measures to prevent illicit exports.

Urges the Government of National Accord to exercise sole and effective oversight over the National Oil Corporation, the Central Bank of Libya, and the Libyan Investment Authority.

Recalling resolutions 2292 (2016), 2357 (2017), 2420 (2018), and 2473 (2019), authorising inspections on the high seas off Libya's coast of vessels bound to or from Libya believed to be carrying arms or related materiel in violation of relevant Security Council resolutions.

Determining that the situation in Libya continues to constitute a threat to international peace and security, and acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Committee must immediately inform relevant Member States about notifications from the Government of National Accord’s focal point regarding vessels transporting petroleum illicitly exported from Libya.

The Government of National Accord must confirm to the Committee when it exercises sole and effective oversight over the National Oil Corporation, the Central Bank of Libya, and the Libyan Investment Authority.

All Member States must comply with the arms embargo and not intervene in the conflict or take measures that exacerbate it. The Government of National Accord must improve implementation of the arms embargo at all entry points.

Member States must report to the Committee on actions taken to implement the travel ban and asset freeze measures. All States must prevent entry into or transit through their territories of designated individuals.

The Security Council intends to ensure that frozen assets are made available to the Libyan people. The mandate of the Panel of Experts is extended until 15 May 2021.

The Panel must provide an interim report by 15 September 2020 and a final report by 15 March 2021. All States and relevant UN bodies must cooperate fully with the Committee and the Panel.

The Security Council calls upon all parties to ensure the safety of the Panel’s members and provide unhindered access to persons, documents, and sites. It affirms its readiness to review the appropriateness of the measures and the mandate of UNSMIL and the Panel. The Security Council decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
